free_text.Learning outcomes: The promise of entrepreneurship as the driver of market processes in the global business environment is reflected in the emergence of entrepreneurship as a distinctive scholarly domain.  This seminar surveys the major streams of research in entrepreneurship including the conceptual foundations of the field, the key controversies and promising empirical approaches used to study the phenomenon of entrepreneurship.  In this seminar, we will review and critically evaluate assigned readings which emphasize current research in entrepreneurship - the factors shaping the identification, evaluation and exploitation of opportunities.
free_text.Content: [li]Primary perspectives on the existence of entrepreneurial opportunities[br/][li]Comparing perspectives on the discovery of entrepreneurial opportunities.[br/][li]The reasons behind why entrepreneurs exploit opportunities.[br/][li]How do external environmental forces influence new firm formation and what are the processes by which new firms are brought into existence and organizational structures emerge[br/][li]How entrepreneurs create the resources they need to pursue opportunities and how they overcome problems due to uncertainty and information asymmetry.[br/][li]How entrepreneurs engage in new transactions in the absence of prices and markets.
free_text.Keywords: Entrepreneurship, theory, contemporary research, new ventures
free_text.Required prior knowledge: Some familiarity with economics, business and philosophy of science
